newsitem.title: UK: Lloyd's faces lower profit returns -analyst.
newsitem.headline: Lloyd's faces lower profit returns -analyst.

text.p: Return on capacity for the Lloyd's insurance market could fall to 4.9 percent this year compared with 10.9 percent in the recently released results for 1994, one analyst said on Monday.
"Rates and conditions are worse than they have been for many years," Syndicate Underwriting Research Limited, said in its 1997 market review. Lloyd's announces its profits three years in arrears.
The years 1993 to 1996 will be viewed as an exceptional period of sustained profitability for Lloyd's, while 1997 could see some painful reminders of the consequences of under-priced risk taking.

SURL noted that capacity -- the maximum amount of premium the market can underwrite -- at Lloyd's rose three percent this year to 10.3 billion stg at a time when rates on most classes of insurance were falling.
"For 1998, rigorous portfolio selection may be more important than it has ever been," Mark Hewlett, managing director of SURL, said in his introduction to the review.
"No-one should be misled about the current state of the market, which, on a global basis, to an outside observer is demonstrating somewhat illogical behaviour," Hewlett said.
SURL's 1997 Syndicate Rating Guide and Market Review rates all Lloyd's 148 underwriting syndicates.
Seven syndicates -- 557, 609, 672, 779, 925, 1028 and 1176 -- received its highest 'A' rating.

On Friday, Lloyd's commentator Chatset forecast little change in the market's total profit for 1995 at around 900 million stg from 1994, although it predicted a fall to around 700 million stg for 1996.
